article:

Over the last decade,the number of students cheating academically has   _   dramatically. Duke University conducted a(n)   _   of 50,000 universities and 18,000 high school students in America. More than 70 percent of the students   _   to having cheated.However,10 years ago,only 56 percent of the students cheated.
This   _   extends far beyond the US. In Asia,where students face great   _   to excel  ,the cheating problem is especially   _  .In many Asian countries,a student's performance is measured   _   by exam scores. And admission to a top school   depends on   passing standardized tests. This test driven culture makes cheating an easy way for students to get   _   in a super competitive academic system.
Last year,24 students in Taiwan   _   chances and ended up in prison   _   they were caught cheating on the University Entrance Exam. The students received answers to test questions   _   cell phones and other electronic devices  . But the pressure to perform well on tests isn't the only thing turning   _   into cheaters. For one,new technology makes cheating   _   than ever. Students now have more choices than just "cheat sheets"   _   in pencil boxes.
Today's students use text messaging to send each other test   _  .Some post questions from standardized tests on Internet bulletin boards  . Students in Asia,  for example  ,have posted questions from the TOEFL and the GRE.
